docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a plan to insure continued care for policyholders of the failed HIP Health Plan of New Jersey misstated the date of the state takeover of the company. It was Nov. 20, 1998, not Sept. 20.
docs.abstract: Correction of February 20 article on plan to insure continued care for policyholders of failed HIP Health Plan of New Jersey

docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed at an increase in the number of people without health insurance, President Clinton will announce on Tuesday that he is establishing a national toll-free telephone number to enroll children in Medicaid and in a separate new health program for people under the age of 19. The phone number is 877-KIDS-NOW (877-543-7669). Callers will be automatically connected to the Medicaid agency or the health department of the state they are calling from. They may then obtain free or low-cost health insurance for their children. Many states allow families to apply by mail.

headline.main: New Effort Aims to Enroll Children in Insurance Plans

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will announce establishment of national toll-free telephone number to enroll children in Medicaid and in separate new health program for people under age of 19; experts in health policy say changes in Federal welfare policy, including landmark 1996 law, have increased number of poor people without health insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I recently scheduled a long-overdue operation that could have been readily carried out in a doctor's office or in a hospital on an outpatient basis. It was nothing serious, but even so, my elderly mother begged me not to rush home because I lived alone. Instead, she urged me to remain in the hospital overnight, in case I needed attention. It's not possible, I argued, explaining with a hint of cynicism that procedures have become so sophisticated and coverage so restrictive that, in all but the most serious cases, patients are supposed to climb right off the operating table and march out the door. Try anyway, she admonished, ''just so I won't sit here worrying.''
docs.abstract: Medical hotels and post-operative recovery centers serve people who are having outpatient surgery but who cannot or prefer not to return home immediately; Louis F Reuter 4th, executive vice president of New York Presbyterian Hospital, which its considering a hotel at its Washington Heights complex, notes these kinds of centers are proliferating to meet changing patterns of patient care; photos of guest residence at Mount Sinai (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive, said today in his State of the County address that he saw the county's financial glass as half-full despite reports that last year's deficit could have swelled to a record $190 million. Speaking in the chamber of the Nassau County Legislature, Mr. Gulotta delivered a speech that he had delayed for more than a month as his office grappled with allegations of brutality and murder at the county jail, a failed employee health care plan that ran $60 million over budget and the deficit, which threatens the county's bond rating and its ability to borrow.

headline.main: Nassau Chief Vows to Hold Line on Taxes Despite Gap

docs.abstract: Thomas S Gulotta, Nassau County Executive, delivers his State of the County address; says he sees county's financial glass as half-full despite reports that last year's deficit could have swelled to record $190 million; insists that budget overruns were small in proportion to county's overall budget of $2.3 billion; promises to hold line on property taxes (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Casting as long a shadow over New York State government as any issue in recent years, health care could dominate this year's legislative session, state officials say, and it is already the subject of one of the fiercest, most complex lobbying wars in memory. Several tightly interwoven questions must be answered: how to spend New York's share of the national tobacco settlement; what to do about the rapidly rising number of New Yorkers without health insurance; whether to accept Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed cuts in Medicaid spending, and how to cope with expected Federal cuts in Medicare.

headline.main: A Fierce Lobbying War Looms in Albany Over Health Care

docs.abstract: New York State officials say that health care could dominate this year's legislative session and that it is already subject of one of most fiercest, most complex lobbying wars in memory; issues facing Legislature include how to spend state's share of national tobacco settlement, what to do about rapidly rising number of New Yorkers without health insurance, whether to accept Gov George Pataki's proposed cuts in Medicaid spending and how to cope with expected Federal cuts in Medicare; at core of disputes is state law that adds $2.6 billion a year in surcharges to hospital bills, mostly to help hospitals pay for training young doctors and caring for poor (M)
